title: Mauricio Saucedo
text:
Mauricio Saucedo Guardia (born August 14, 1985 in <a href="Santa%20Cruz%20de%20la%20Sierra">Santa Cruz de la Sierra</a>) is a <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>n <a href="association%20football">football</a> midfielder. He was also a member of the <a href="Bolivia%20national%20football%20team">Bolivia national team</a>.
Club career.
Saucedo developed his skills at Tahuichi Academy. In 2003, at age 18 he reached professional football when he signed for <a href="Club%20Bol%C3%ADvar">Bolívar</a>, although he made his official debut in the Bolivian league with <a href="Iberoamericana">Iberoamericana</a> later that year. In 2004, he joined <a href="La%20Paz%20F.C.">La Paz F.C.</a> but his appearances were sporadic, mainly coming off the bench.
The following year he transferred to <a href="Club%20San%20Jos%C3%A9">San José</a>, and his career finally began to sprout. In short time, Saucedo became one of the most valuable young prospects in the country and helped the club in obtaining the 2007 Clausura title.
In January 2009, he was signed by <a href="Universitario%20de%20Sucre">Universitario de Sucre</a> along with other important players to fortify the squad before facing <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a>.
In February 2010, he travelled to Ukraine and signed for first division club <a href="FC%20Chornomorets%20Odesa">FC Chornomorets Odesa</a>. By August of that year, Saucedo returned to Bolivia and joined hometown club <a href="Oriente%20Petrolero">Oriente Petrolero</a>. During his spell at the club he won the <a href="2010%20Liga%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Profesional%20Boliviano%20season">2010 Clausura</a>.
In July 2011, he was signed by Portuguese club <a href="Vit%C3%B3ria%20S.C.">Vitória S.C.</a>. After making only one appearance since the beginning of the season, he criticized manager <a href="Rui%20Vit%C3%B3ria">Rui Vitória</a> for not giving him enough playing time which led to the club releasing the player on the December 16, 2011.
He was signed by Brazilian club <a href="Clube%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Bragantino">Bragantino</a> on January 5, 2012. Following an unsuccessful stint Saucedo found himself signing for <a href="The%20Strongest">The Strongest</a> in May of that year. After a season with the "atigrados", Saucedo moved to Universitario de Sucre for the second time in his career and helped the club obtain the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Liga%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Profesional%20Boliviano%20season">2014 Clausura</a>. On June 18, 2015 Saucedo returned to Oriente Petrolero with the illusion of winning another championship for the .
